Comment: This game illustrates how strong a Queen can be. Sometimes it can even outplay two Rooks and a Bishop! But more of that later.

No thanks!

Worth an exclamation mark, I think - and a very picturesque position with two White pieces en prise. 18. -, bxc6 is not desirable because of 19. Bxc6 which pins both Queen and Rook. If Black chooses to take the Bishop instead, then follows: 19. Ne7+, Kh8 20. Ng6+, hxg6 21. Qxf8+, Kh7 22. Rxc8, Rxc8 23. Qxc8 with a solid advantage for White.

This turns out to be a bad idea. The Rook should have kept protecting the f7 Pawn, but Black is very cramped. Now comes a surprising sacrifice, denting the Black Kingside completely.

The critical moment of the game. Of course 26. -, exf5 27. Qxe8 was hopeless, but now White has no more checks, and his Queen is still under fire from the Knight. It took me a long time of analysis to find the only solution: Another sacrifice!

Another !. Black has a winning material advantage (even two Rooks vs. Queen is generally better), but White has created a mating net.

Black can choose between 31. -, Rg8 32. Qxh5 mate or 31. Any move -, Qg7 mate - but he chose to resign instead. One of my best games on Gameknot, and I would like to thank my opponent for the good fight.
